paper_metadata.title: Disability-Inclusive Graduation programme in Uganda: Study protocol for a cluster randomised controlled trial

program_information.target_population: Ultra-poor people with disabilities and/or women

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Participants receive unconditional cash transfers for 6 months, training, access to savings-and-loans groups, and a capital asset that forms the basis of their new livelihood.

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: Participants receive unconditional cash transfers for 6 months, training, access to savings-and-loans groups, and a capital asset that forms the basis of their new livelihood.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: The primary outcome of the trial is per-capita household consumption.
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Clusters are randomly selected prior to implementation, resulting in 96 intervention and 89 control clusters.

bonus_information.qualitative_evidence_citation: These activities are complemented by a process evaluation to understand DIG programme implementation, mechanisms, and context using complementary qualitative and quantitative methods.

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The Disability-Inclusive Graduation (DIG) programme targets ultra-poor people with disabilities and/or women living in rural Uganda.
evidence_citations.country_citation: The Disability-Inclusive Graduation (DIG) programme targets ultra-poor people with disabilities and/or women living in rural Uganda.
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The Disability-Inclusive Graduation (DIG) programme targets ultra-poor people with disabilities and/or women living in rural Uganda.
